results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film captures a wedding in Goroka, featuring Evelyn Sinclair and friends. The happy couple take off in an airplane for their honeymoon. Relates to reel B2003518.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan) 00:00:00:00 guests at wedding
00:00:25:00 wedding car decorated
00:00:28:00 happy couple cutting the wedding cake
00:01:01:00 bride and groom posing in front of plane; ‘Just Hitched’ sprayed onto the front of the plane
00:01:25:00 happy couple takes off in airplane

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore and Thailand, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film captures a trip to Southeast Asia including Hong Kong, Japan, possibly Thailand and Singapore, including cruising around bays, along rivers, scenic views, traditional dance, temple visits and a visit to Kranji War Cemetery, Singapore.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:34:00 Australian Naval Ship in the bay, most likely Hong Kong
00:01:13:00 young boys in small wooden boats appear to be almost knocked over by the ferry or cruise ship the filmmaker is on
00:03:57:00 Shining Star Ferry in Hong Kong
00:04:51:00 plane to Japan
00:07:05:00 a trip to a waterfall, filmmaker’s wife and friends with Japanese friend or tour guide
00:07:53:00 scenic views of possibly Osaka
00:09:17:00 train station, possibly Kansai Station; we see a Kansai Paints billboard behind train
00:10:09:00 a visit to temples surrounded by cherry blossom, perhaps in Kyoto
00:11:10:00 ice skating perhaps in a function centre, skaters dressed in Scottish dress, then Russian, then cowboys
00:13:08:00 possibly views from an airport, a carpark surrounded by mountains, possibly Thailand, as short street views have writing in what appears to be Thai
00:13:35:00 a cruise along a river, markets of people selling food and people living in small houses along the river surrounded by forest and jungle
00:15:40:00 traditional dancers performing and elephant performing tasks for an audience
00:17:05:00 more traditional dancing
00:17:42:00 we see a sign for Kanji War Cemetery, Singapore, a short trip to the memorial
00:18:30:00 snake charmers in a city mall
00:19:22:00 feeding monkeys in a park
00:20:17:00 exotic planet and orchid display
00:21:04:00 possibly back in Australia; a car and boat parade with some of the cars flying the Australian flag

results.title: [Brookes Family Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family visit to the beach and backyard play in Point Lonsdale c1950s -1960s. We see the children (James, Andrew and Margaret) with their mother and father playing on the seashore, building sandcastles together and drawing pictures in the sand. Joined by their pet dog, the children fill their buckets with sand and play with seaweed washed up onto the beach. There are good closeups of the children, reflecting examples of children’s fashion and hairstyles of the era.

We see the children venture out to the edge of the water and then play along the top of the seawall. There is great delight while eating ice cream from cones, and tears shed when an adult takes an uninvited taste.

The second, third and fourth sections of the film show the children on a summer’s day in a backyard. Tricycles, a blow-up wading pool with the backyard hose leading into it, swings and a sand pit create a great snapshot of children’s recreation, toys, and equipment particular to the era. We also see a young boy kicking what appears to be an American shaped football and two boys playing with toy cars and a toy police car.

The fifth section of the film shows a young baby being held by her mother. We then see the baby lying in her pram and being closely inspected and entertained by her older sibling.

We then go back to the beach with three very young children playing on the water’s edge with their mother beside them. Adults sit on the sand socialising, and there are scenes on the veranda of a holiday house. We see great examples of beach fashion, women’s hats, and children’s swimsuits.

This film shows examples of Victoria in the summertime, beach, women’s fashion and children’s fashion, children’s swim wear, vintage toys and a perambulator, children’s leisure and recreation activities that reflect the time.

Originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:18:00 Mother and three boys playing in the sand
00:02:25:00 Children filling buckets with sand
00:02:36:00 Two children filling buckets with sand
00:03:09:00 Young boy crawling along the sea wall
00:03:34:00 Eating ice creams from cones, offering to share with passers by
00:03:50:00 Close up of eating ice cream
00:06:25:00 Three children on their tricycles with backyard swing
00:06:56:00 Two boys swing on their backyard bench swing
00:07:03 :00 Three children on swing
00:07:24:00 Children playing in sandpit
00:08:36:00 Nice wide shot of children playing on swing and in the sandpit
00:09:52:00 Three children playing in blow up wading pool
00:10:17:00 Three children crowded on a backyard swing together
00:10:32:00 Children trying to move wading pool full of water across the grass
00:12:44:00 Boys play with toy police car in sand pit
00:14:08:00 Children play with what appears to be an American shaped football
00:15:32:00 Boy riding on vintage tricycle in front of house
00:17:13:00 Baby in vintage pram with sibling peering in and attempting to play
00:17:53:00 Mother and three very young children sit at the water’s edge
00:18:15:00 Very young child at water’s edge – good example of children’s swim wear
00:20:28:00 Family on veranda of holiday house with seascape in background
00:21:48:00 Three women sitting on the beach wearing great hats
00:22:51:00 Great family beach scene as above

results.title: [Beam Software: interview 3]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Andrew Bailey and Trevor Nuridin discuss how they both entered the games industry and their work at Beam’s publishing arm, Melbourne House. They talk candidly about the culture at Beam and the reasons why they left to start Tantalus Media together in 1994.

results.title: [Australian olympic team visits Bayer works at Leverkusen on June 22nd 1936]
results.brief_description: Documentary from 1936 about the visit of the Australian Olympic team to the Bayer Works, manufacturers of Bayer Aspirins and APC powders, at Leverkusen, near Cologne, Germany before travelling to Berlin for the Olympic Games. The Australian Olympic team are shown arriving in Cologne, Germany, and being met by representatives of the Bayer works. They move on to a casino where they have breakfast. The team’s chaperone, Mrs. Ferguson talks to long distance runner, Daryl Backhouse. At the Bayer Works factory team members Alf Watson and Pat Norton look at a machine which fills and caps vials. The team moves on and looks at a machine which makes Bayer aspirins. At a dock on the Rhine river, where raw materials for the factory are unloaded, team members L. Cook, Duncan Gray and Bill Dixson are shown standing around and chatting. After a visit to the factory the team are shown sight seeing around Cologne. Shots of a booklet signing are followed by shots of Berlin. As the Australian team disembark from their train on their arrival at a railway station in Berlin, the German Navy are shown playing ‘God save the King’ on the station’s platform. Words of the sound film are spoken by Mr. Alderson, manager of the Australian Olympic team.
results.title_for_label: [Australian olympic team visits Bayer works at Leverkusen on June 22nd 1936]
results.description: Documentary from 1936 about the visit of the Australian Olympic team to the Bayer Works, manufacturers of Bayer Aspirins and APC powders, at Leverkusen, near Cologne, Germany before travelling to Berlin for the Olympic Games. The Australian Olympic team are shown arriving in Cologne, Germany, and being met by representatives of the Bayer works. They move on to a casino where they have breakfast. The team’s chaperone, Mrs. Ferguson talks to long distance runner, Daryl Backhouse. At the Bayer Works factory team members Alf Watson and Pat Norton look at a machine which fills and caps vials. The team moves on and looks at a machine which makes Bayer aspirins. At a dock on the Rhine river, where raw materials for the factory are unloaded, team members L. Cook, Duncan Gray and Bill Dixson are shown standing around and chatting. After a visit to the factory the team are shown sight seeing around Cologne. Shots of a booklet signing are followed by shots of Berlin. As the Australian team disembark from their train on their arrival at a railway station in Berlin, the German Navy are shown playing ‘God save the King’ on the station’s platform. Words of the sound film are spoken by Mr. Alderson, manager of the Australian Olympic team.

results.title: ....And everything nice
results.creator_credit: Norma Adams and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description: Through the process of consciousness raising, women develop new expectations for themselves and a sense of self-worth. The process is marked by an understanding of the ways in which society teaches women to assume passive roles in directing their own lives. In asserting themselves for the first time, many women experience fears and conflicts about the future of women as members of society.

results.title: (dis)LOCATIONs symposium
results.creator_credit: Anna Munster, Peter Weibel, Dennis Del Favero and Jeffrey Shaw
results.brief_description:
A conference about fragmentation of ‘community’, urbanisation and the collapse of locale and neighbourhood, the erosion of the private spaces of the sexual and familial. These have emerged as thematics attributable to the restructuring and divergent flows of new information economies and mediascapes.

Featuring key note speakers including Jeffrey Shaw, Dennis Del Favero, Agnes Hegedus, Susan Norrie, Peter Weibel, Ursula Frohne, Lev Manovich.

results.title: #hairforfreedom
results.brief_description: International celebrities including Oscar award-winning Juliette Binoche and Marion Cotillard have taken to social media to express their solidarity with protests in Iran, ignited by the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini while in the custody of Iran’s morality police for violating the nation’s dress code. The videos, which document women symbolically cutting off their own hair, have been compiled and posted on an Instagram account “soutienfemmesiran” — which translates as “support women in Iran” – using the hashtag #hairforfreedom.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

International celebrities like Oscar winners Juliette Binoche and Marion Cotillard have taken to social media to express their solidarity with Iranian protestors, following the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini while in the custody of Iran’s morality police for violating the nation’s dress code. The videos, which show women symbolically cutting off their hair, are compiled on Instagram account soutienfemmesiran (support women in Iran), using the hashtag #hairforfreedom.

Social media’s reach allows online communities to collectively condemn actions across the world – supporters may not be able to be there physically, but social gives them a voice – tethering protestors on the ground with human rights advocates and activists, resulting in support, as the video below shows, that can result in causes being advanced on traditional media channels.
description_for_label: International celebrities like Oscar winners Juliette Binoche and Marion Cotillard have taken to social media to express their solidarity with Iranian protestors, following the death of 22-year-old Mahsa Amini while in the custody of Iran’s morality police for violating the nation’s dress code. The videos, which show women symbolically cutting off their hair, are compiled on Instagram account soutienfemmesiran (support women in Iran), using the hashtag #hairforfreedom. Social media’s reach allows online communities to collectively condemn actions across the world – supporters may not be able to join protests, but social gives them a voice.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: [A New map for Canada]
results.creator_credit: John H. Tyo, Robert Anderson, James Beveridge and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
This film is a survey of Canada in terms of its national air service. Far below a Trans-Canada Airlines (T.C.A.) passenger plane, the new map, a continent wide, unrolls, patterned with high mountains and orchard valleys, prairies with their rectangular grainfields, the Great Lakes and the eastern farmlands. One T.C.A. flight soars over Cleveland and New York; another service crosses Québec and the Maritimes; while a trans-oceanic air liner heads out across the broad Atlantic.
Title and credits missing.
